# Day 921

![Everyday more of humanity's brain power is being spent on the digital world](https://miro.medium.com/1*E0Uj_Vrp6CxiEcBltGfNhQ.png)

Today I started a new book, [Robert Greene's Mastery](https://amzn.to/3TQDn2L), and I am loving it so far. The introduction discusses how humans are special not for our physical prowess, which is actually much weaker than most other animals. It's our ability to use our brains. To organize socially. To have an intuition and to think about the future. I highlighted some parts I'll share here.

> This is the real secret: the brain that we possess is the work of six million years of development, and more than anything else, this evolution of the brain was designed to lead us to mastery, the latent power within us all.

> Our exact genetic make up has never happened before and will never be repeated.

> It is the height of stupidity to believe that in the course of your short life, your few decades of consciousness, you can somehow rewire the configurations of your brain through technology and wishful thinking, overcoming the effect of six million years of development. To go against the grain might bring temporary distraction, but time will mercilessly expose your weakness and impatience.

All of these are quotes from the introduction. Greene seems to caution against trying to shortcut this evolutionary heritage, arguing that attempts to rapidly rewire our brains might be counterproductive. This perspective raises interesting questions about the relationship between our biological inheritance and our efforts at self-improvement. In an age where quick fixes and instant gratification are constantly marketed, Greene's words serve as a sobering reminder of the deep-rooted nature of human cognition and development.

Our brains, the product of millions of years of evolutionary refinement, have been shaped by the challenges and environments faced by our ancestors. This long history has endowed us with remarkable capabilities - abstract thinking, complex problem-solving, and the ability to learn and adapt. However, it has also ingrained certain patterns of behavior and learning that cannot be easily overridden by sheer will or technological interventions.

The tension between our evolutionary heritage and modern aspirations for rapid self-improvement is particularly evident in today's information age. For much of human history, knowledge was a scarce resource, carefully guarded by a select few. Libraries were rare, books were precious, and formal education was a privilege reserved for the elite. This scarcity not only created power imbalances but also limited the pace of innovation and personal growth for the majority of the population.

Fast forward to the present day, and we find ourselves in an era of unprecedented information abundance. The internet, digital libraries, online courses, and global connectivity have democratized access to knowledge in ways our ancestors could scarcely have imagined. This shift has the potential to level playing fields, accelerate innovation, and empower individuals from all walks of life to pursue learning and self-improvement at a pace and scale never before possible.

Yet, this very abundance presents its own set of challenges. The sheer volume of available information can be overwhelming, leading to what many term "information overload." It's easier than ever to fall into the trap of shallow, scattered learning rather than engaging in the deep, focused study that true mastery requires. The ease of access to information can create an illusion of expertise, where watching a few online videos or reading a handful of articles is mistaken for genuine understanding and skill.

Moreover, the quality of information varies wildly in this new landscape. Credible sources often compete for attention with unreliable or misleading content, making it challenging for learners to discern what information is truly valuable. Especially considering that most of the quality information is no longer coming from our institutions, but instead from the independent voices not bought and paid for. All of this noise can lead to confusion, misdirection, and wasted effort in the pursuit of self-improvement.

The constant stream of new information and the addictive nature of many digital platforms can also fragment our attention, making it difficult to focus on long-term, in-depth learning. Our brains, evolved for a world of scarce but vital information, can struggle to cope with this deluge, leading to stress, anxiety, and a sense of always falling behind.

In this context, Greene's warning takes on added significance. While we have unprecedented access to information and tools for self-improvement, true mastery and personal growth still require time, dedication, and deep engagement. Our brains are not designed for rapid-fire, superficial learning but thrive on sustained focus, practice, and the gradual building of neural pathways.

This is not to say that we should reject modern tools and methods for self-improvement. Rather, it suggests that we need to approach self-improvement with a nuanced understanding of our biological heritage. We must learn to harness the power of modern technology and information access while respecting the fundamental ways in which our brains learn and develop.

Effective self-improvement in the modern age requires a delicate balance. We must cultivate the ability to focus deeply, to be selective with the information we consume, and to commit to long-term learning processes. It means embracing the idea that true expertise takes time and resisting the urge for quick fixes or shortcuts that promise instant results but deliver little lasting value.

In practical terms, this might involve creating environments and habits that allow for sustained, undistracted work. It means being ruthless in curating our sources of information, seeking out high-quality, in-depth resources rather than a constant stream of shallow content. It involves understanding that mastery in any field is a journey of years, not days or weeks, and having the patience to allow our neural pathways to develop over time.

Moreover, in a world of infinite possibilities, choosing where to focus our limited time and cognitive resources becomes even more critical. We don't have the luxury of becoming experts in everything. The key is to choose wisely where to invest our efforts, to specialize deeply rather than spread ourselves too thin.

While we should appreciate and utilize the unprecedented access to knowledge and tools for self-improvement that we now enjoy, we must also respect the biological realities of how we learn and develop expertise. True mastery and meaningful personal growth are not about consuming vast amounts of information quickly or finding shortcuts around our evolutionary heritage. Instead, they are about deep engagement, focused practice, and the patience to work with, rather than against, the grain of our cognitive evolution. By finding this balance, we can hope to achieve genuine self-improvement that is both profound and lasting. To achieve mastery of the thing we love.

9/28/24

Conor Jay Chepenik
